awd_titl_txt: RUI: CAS: Carbon Dioxide Hydrogenation to Light Olefins over Carbon Nanosphere Encapsulated Metal/Metal Carbide Core-Shell Catalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
Carbon-rich fossil fuels, such as coal, oil, and natural gas, have been heavily utilized to power human civilization. This has resulted in massive emissions of carbon dioxide (CO2), a potent greenhouse gas, to the environment. There is an urgent need to mitigate the negative impacts of these emissions on the environment. Efficient utilization of CO2 to produce chemicals and fuels is one potential solution. This research project is examining the conversion of CO2 to light olefins. Olefins are important chemicals and raw materials heavily used for the packaging, plastic processing, construction, and textile industries. The huge market demand for light olefins offers a great opportunity for this project to significantly impact CO2 utilization technology. While significant advances have been made, considerable challenges remain for the discovery and development of practical catalysts for this transformation. In this project, Professor Cheng Zhang of the Long Island University (Post), New York is developing a new approach using carbon nanosphere (CNS) encapsulated metal catalysts for CO2 conversion to light olefins. Dr. Zhang is studying CNS encapsulated iron-cobalt catalysts and investigating their fundamental reaction mechanisms. These fundamental insights are being used to design new catalysts that perform much more efficiently. Dr. Zhang is actively engaged in training the next generation of undergraduates in chemistry education and research. Dr. Zhang’s lab involves diverse students from various majors in this interdisciplinary setting. This research is further serving as a platform to inspire students from underrepresented groups to become scientists.

With the funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Division of Chemistry, Dr. Zhang of the Long Island University (Post), New York is developing fundamental understanding of a class of new catalysts, carbon nanosphere (CNS) encapsulated metal/metal carbide nanoparticle core-shell structures, for catalytic CO2 conversion to light olefins. This project is significant in studying the composition, structure, and catalytic performances of CNS encapsulated metal/metal carbide catalysts by integrating synthesis, testing, and characterization of the catalysts with multiple compositional and structural variables. Specifically, the CNS encapsulated Fe catalyst provides an intriguing catalytic performance for CO2 conversion to light olefins. A variety of characterization instruments including in-situ time-resolved X-ray diffraction (TR-XRD), ex-situ x-ray absorption near edge structure spectroscopy (XANES), and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) are utilized to achieve a fundamental understanding of the reaction pathways and the confinement effect that contributes to the superior performance. Furthermore, with CNS serves as a nanocontainer, the encapsulated Fe-Co catalyst is expected to exhibit enhanced catalytic performances due to the synergistic effect of the bimetals, together with the unique confinement effect of CNS. By synthetically changing the relative shell thickness and core dimeter, a core-shell nano-environment of encapsulated active Fe/Co core species in the CNS shells provides an ideal and practical model system to explore the fundamentals of structural variables on the role of confinement in catalysis. This project has the dual impact of removing CO2 from the atmosphere while generating desired commercial products. Dr. Zhang incorporates undergraduate research and education as a very significant component. Dr. Zhang is developing a training-learning platform that allows undergraduate and high school students to gain valuable skills in synthesis, catalyst evaluation techniques and basic characterization, in conjunction with their quantitative and critical thinking skills, which paves the way for their future career development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report (for General Public)

 

Award Title: RUI: CAS: Carbon Dioxide Hydrogenation to Light Olefins over Carbon Nanosphere Encapsulated Metal/Metal Carbide Core-Shell Catalysts

PI: Cheng Zhang, Associate Professor, Long Island University (Post)

Award Period of Performance: Start Date: 09/01/2020 End Date: 08/31/2023

NSF Award ID: 1955521

 

This work has significant impacts in understanding the CNS encapsulated core-shell catalysts for CO2 conversion, enhancing research capacity and opportunity for undergraduate research and education. 

Scientific findings: We synthesized a unique carbon nanosphere (CNS)-encapsulated Fe-Co catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins and demonstrated that the synthesized CNS-Fe-Co is a promising catalyst for direct CO2 conversion to light olefins with favorable catalytic activity when compared with CNS-Fe and CNS-Co under the same testing conditions. The superior performance of the catalyst CNS-Fe-Co can be attributed to the Fe-Co synergistic effect and the confinement effect of CNS. The present findings provide a clear understanding of the roles of Fe-Co interactions over CNS encapsulated Fe-Co catalysts and the core-shell nano-environment offers an ideal and practical model system for catalytic CO2 hydrogenation studies.

Enhancing Research Capacity and Opportunity: The research project provides an important opportunity to train undergraduate students and high school students as future work force in the USA. This project has successfully attracted 23 undergraduate students and 2 high school students through the funding period. This research benefits from participation and hands-on research experience in a range of technical disciplines including catalyst syntheses, reactor operations, catalytic processes, analytical methods, and state-of-art characterizations. Involving undergraduates in research is a crucial part of their education, not only to hone their quantitative and critical thinking skills but also to aspire their practical appreciation and understanding of how scientific research is conducted. This research serves an educational platform to inspire more underrepresented groups to become future scientists. One recent graduate who has worked in my research lab for three years, wrote to me, ?conducting research with Dr. Zhang was one of the greatest experiences that I have had in my life. Working with her has shaped me into a more disciplined, focused, and informed person; particularly in the field of catalysis. Compared to everything else that college had to offer, research has been the most instrumental in helping me find my path in life. While my lectures and labs taught me the basic principles of chemistry, this research pushed me to figure out how to hold myself accountable for my responsibilities, problem solve, and taught me to never accept anything the way that it is?.

Bridge the gap between classroom and the real-world: The project has important impact to teaching and educational experience of both undergraduate and high school students. For students, the most efficient way to learn is to apply what learned in the classroom to the real-world. This research opportunity successfully bridged the gap between the classroom and the real-world. Students applied the knowledge learned in the classroom to the research lab, which is the practice field before their entering the real-world.  Most students showed great passion and excitement after working in my research lab and their attitude influenced and inspired more students to join in and they believe that they are doing something that they may change the world.

Students achievements: The 23 undergraduate students all have their individual project and they learned how to handle their project independently with critical thinking, problem-solving skills and sense of responsibility and ownership of their project. Their motivation and passion drove them working hard to deliver their project. They all participated in the national, international, regional and campus-wide conferences for poster and oral presentations. Work led to 7 peer-reviewed journals and 60 conference presentations (26 national and international conferences poster presentations, 12 regional conferences oral presentations, and 22 campus-wide undergraduate research symposium poster presentations).

Modified by: Cheng Zhang
